content: Hallo, ich vermute, dass es sich um ein IMAP-Konto handelt und dass du den Ordner Posteingang meinst. Bitte berichtigen, wenn ich mich irre. Erste Maßnahme: R-Klick auf den betreffenden Ordner < Eigenschaften > Reparieren... Häufig wird das augenscheinliche "Verschwinden" oder Nicht-Anzeigen von Nachrichten durch eine schlecht angepasste Nachrichten-Ansicht der Nachrichtenliste hervorgerufen. Hast du vielleicht den Schnellfilter aktiviert?
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Hallo und vielen Dank für Ihre schnelle Rückmeldung. Ja, es handelt sich hierbei um einen IMAP-Konto.

Ich habe Ihren Vorschlag, den betroffenen Ordner über Eigenschaften > Reparieren wiederherzustellen, bereits durchgeführt. Leider hat dies das Problem nicht gelöst, die aktuellen E-Mails werden weiterhin nicht angezeigt.

Zusätzlich möchte ich erwähnen, dass der Schnellfilter bei mir deaktiviert ist, sodass es daran ebenfalls nicht liegen kann.

Ich wäre Ihnen dankbar, wenn Sie mir weitere Lösungsmöglichkeiten oder einen detaillierten Ansatz zur Behebung des Problems nennen könnten.

Vielen Dank vorab für Ihre Unterstützung und liebe Grüße Dave
creator: dave_182

content:
Hast du schon im Webmail deines E-Mailproviders überprüft, ob die selben Nachrichten auch dort fehlen? Rufst du neuerdings deine E-Mails auch auf einem Smartphone ab? Gibt es eine relativ aktuelle Sicherung des Thunderbird Profils?

Verschwundene Nachrichten wieder zu finden oder wiederherzustellen ist so mit das am schwersten zu lösende Problem in einem Mail-Client und kann manchmal nur durch eine Fernwartung (oder IT-Spezialist vor Ort) erfolgreich beendet werden. Es gibt einfach keine fertigen Rezepte dafür, fast jeder Fall ist anders gelagert und erfordert meist einen Blick auf den Bildschirm. Häufig ist der Verlust endgültig, da Thunderbird-Benutzer (wie auch der durchschnittliche PC Benutzer) keine Backups ihrer Daten durchführen.
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Hello,

ludmilla.sztabowicz said
Usually I first get my mails thourgh Orange mail, then they appear on my thunderbird mail box and simultaneously disappear from my Orange mail box, but today, after I saw them on Orange, they seem to have disappeared and are nowhere to be found on my thunderbird box.

I presume that you are using the POP protocol for your Orange email account. Maybe you deleted those business email inadvertently in the Orange webmail ? Did you contact the Orange email services ?

In the meantime: in Thunderbird right-click on the Orange account's Inbox (in French "Courrier entrant") > Properties > Repair Folder. If this doesn't help verify if those 100 emails are in the Trash folder. Do you use mail filters? Did you activate the "Quick Filter"? How big in MB or GB is your Inbox folder?
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Hello, Thank you very much for your answer.

Please find my answers below.

I presume that you are using the POP protocol for your Orange email account. Yes

Maybe you deleted those business email inadvertently in the Orange webmail ? No, they disappeared as they usually do once my thunderbird is open.

Did you contact the Orange email services ? Yes, they told me they couldn't do anything since according to them it is a Thunderbird problem.

In the meantime: in Thunderbird right-click on the Orange account's Inbox (in French "Courrier entrant") > Properties > Repair Folder. I have tried this solution but it didn't change a thing.

If this doesn't help verify if those 100 emails are in the Trash folder. Nothing in the Trash folder

Do you use mail filters? No

Did you activate the "Quick Filter"? The "Quick filter" seemed to be on, but I don't remember having activated, and once desactivated it hasn't changed anything.

How big in MB or GB is your Inbox folder? 3,4 Go

And just one last detail : as weird as it seems, I believe these mails did appear in my thunderbird box before disappearing.

Thank you so much for your help.
creator: ludmilla.sztabowicz

content: 3.4 GB equivalent of several thousand emails are not really hopeful news for an Inbox folder disorder. The corresponding Inbox file in the Thunderbird profile is the one with most trafic: new messages downloaded, messages deleted or archived or moved to other folders, this file is constantly rewritten and exposed to potential damage. Retrieving "disappeared" messages is the most challenging help, it's like searching a needle in a haystack. Il me semble que vous êtes en France. Si vous le souhaitez vous pouvez me contacter en utilisant mon nick et en y ajoutant arobase free point fr

content:
It will be 'IP Address' - some spammers are identified by the IP address they use. Certainly, an IP address is normally changed after a reboot of the laptop so the problem shouldn't persist. However, Spam can be identified as such by numerous different criteria by servers.

I won't go into the list and circumstances. All I'll say is that the error message you posted does not indicate that your emails were being labelled as 'spam'. Would you post a screenshot of the pop up message you're getting?

What you posted indicates that Thunderbird is not able to connect to the ESMTP Server because of an authentication error. Have you checked the SMTP settings with your Email Provider's posted settings to make sure they match?

content:
Okay. I want you to go back to where those five items are and we need to change some. 'Comcast' was a company or service related to Xfinity. But you aren't with them anymore. You told me that you are with Frontier and their settings need to be entered.

So, in order:

comcast Change to Frontier. This won't do anything except call your account 'Frontier'. But it's just a bit of tidying up.

smtp.comcast.net This must be changed to smtp.frontier.com Type this exactly as I have with no spaces but include the dots. No upper case, either. This is the server that TB will try to log in to. My guess is that it can't log on because you no longer have an account and the connection is being refused.

port 465 Correct. Leave it.

SSL/TLS Correct. Leave it.

normal password Correct. Leave it.

Your 'User name' that I told you not to send should be your current email address - NOT the old one. If it's not the right one, change it.

Then click on 'OK' and x out of the Tabs to get back to your email interface. Now see if you can receive email. There may still be a setting that needs changing - but TB should throw up an error message if there's another problem.

Let me know what happens.

content:
actually I already solved this. I found the specific email profile file I needed to copy to the new computer. Of course I had to rename it before completing the transfer but it worked just fine. What I did discover is that the export feature does not work. It created a ZIP file that was supposedly 8 gb but trying to read the file resulted in a message saying the file was invalid and was actually empty.

That was when I decided to re-open the profile folder and finding the profile I needed under mail.

So I accomplished my goal of restoring that email profile to the new computer.

Yes,, David, that was what I meant and we can mark this question solved. Thanks.
creator: Rosaliy-Lynne

content:
I'm glad all is well. There is a warning when selecting the tools>export menu that states not to exceed 2 gb, but the message is rarely seen. I generally suggest copying the thunderbird folder, not the profile folder because that eliminates the issue of renaming the profile. For your future use, I share those steps here:

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
You can tell Thunderbird what to do with messages classified as junk. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages#w_junk-filter-settings

You'll still get them anyway, there is no way around that once your email address is 'burned'. But you won't see them in your Inbox anymore.

Also see how to train the filter: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages#w_training-the-junk-filter

content:
La Password principale (https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/password-principale-thunderbird) che è possibile impostare all'avvio serve ad impedire che un utente non autorizzato possa scaricare la posta dai server configurati.

Saltando l'inserimento della password, gli account vengono caricati senza password. Se sono impostati per scaricare la posta all'avvio allora chiederanno in sequenza l'inserimento delle password. La procedura non può essere interrotta come ulteriore misura di sicurezza perché l'utente legittimo potrebbe aver attivato un LOG con cui eventualmente rintracciare attività sospette.

In altre parole, se non hai bisogno di una Password principale ti conviene disattivarla -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/password-principale-thunderbird#w_rimuovere-la-password-principale

Se invece preferisci averla attiva, dei accettarne il funzionamento che come detto risponde a delle esigenze di sicurezza.
creator: @next

content:
Ho tolto la spunta a scarica posta all'avvio ma comunque appare un popup del primo account google dove chiede se Thunderbird può inviare o ricevere mail, accedere ai contatti e calendari. Chiunque può impostare no a mia insaputa poi se entro con la password che succede? Apparentemente non ricevo messaggi nella gmail perché qualcuno prrima ha cliccato su non consentire sul popup? Per capire.

Inoltre se non inserisco la password posso ancora entrare nel programma, vedere gli indirizzi mail e modificare i parametri degli account e vedere e cancellare i messaggi email dei vari account.

A che serve la password? Solo a non far scaricare i nuovi messaggi? Io ho inserita solo per crittografare i messaggi di posta sul pc. Sono l'unico utente del pc. Ma se entro nel programma a fare quello che voglio anche senza password, a cosa serve oltre a non ricevere e inviare nuovi messaggi?

Non risco a capire, pardon!
creator: ertedibo

content: L'ho già scritto sopra: la Password principale serve solo ad impedire ad un utente non autorizzato di scaricare i nuovi messaggi.
creator: @next

content: Grazie! E a criptare i messaggi? Io posso benissimo togliere la ricezione all'avvio, così se dovessi sbagliarmi riuscirei a chiudere abbastanza velocemente Thunderbird. Ma la password la lascerei solo se effettivamente i messaggi vengono criptati. Diversamente dato che il pc è solo mio, non lascerei la password.
creator: ertedibo

content:
Non ci sono funzioni per la crittografia dei messaggi. Questo perché la protezione dei dati è affidata alla gestione dei permessi del sistema operativo.

Se vuoi che i messaggi siani cifrati sposta il profilo utente di Thunderbird su un drive cifrato, reale o virtuale. Come quelli che ad esempio puoi creare con VeraCrypt.
creator: @next

content: Ok, grazie!

content: UPDATE I took the following steps on January 5 and 6 to troubleshoot the issue, but it still wasn’t working: 1. Verified that I had internet access since other emails were working. 2. Verified IMAP settings for Gmail (imap.gmail.com), port number (993 for SSL/TLS), and authentication method (OAuth2). 3. Double-checked that Gmail IMAP was enabled in the account settings. 4. Ensured the VPN was disabled. 5. Checked Downdetector (https://downdetector.ca/status/gmail/map/) to confirm there were no reported issues with Gmail. However, on January 7, the email started working again. I’m not sure why or how, but the issue has been resolved, and the email is now back up and running.

content:
Prova a fare queste operazioni di manutenzione:

  1. Fare un backup integrale del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo
  2. Compattare le cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle
  3. Riavviare Thunderbird
  4. Se il problema non è risolto, ricostruire l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
  5. Riavviare Thunderbird
  6. Se il problema non si è ancora risolto: click destro sulla cartella che contiene la mail illeggibile -> Proprietà -> [Ripara la cartella]

content: What text are you getting at the bottom left of the program when you try to download manually. Does it connect to the server? Does it say there are no messages to download? What is it reporting?
creator: frisée

content: Thanks again. When I tried to download manually, here is the error message The certificate for pop.domainname is not valid for that server. Someone could be trying to impersonate the server and you should not continue.
creator: htn1972

content:
I take it that you have obscured the name of the server - so I can't check the name of the provider. Please access your Email Provider's web pages to check the correct connection settings. They may have altered the servers or ports.

However, as it talks about a 'certificate', it is probably informing you that the security certificate for the server has now expired and lapsed so that Thunderbird cannot be sure that it is secure to make the connection to.

Usually, a message like this asks whether you wish to override the warning and, personally, I wouldn't. I would be contacting the Email Provider to find out what's going on.
creator: frisée

content: Thanks again. I obscured the name. Let me give it to you again. The certificate for pop.msnucleus.org is not valid for that server. Someone could be trying to impersonate the server and you should not continue.
creator: htn1972

content: Yes, exactly. TB is issuing you with a warning that the certificate being offered as authenticity, safety and security for that server is *not valid*. It's warning you not to continue. All the error messages I've seen like this normally give an override button but, honestly, I wouldn't click on it. I'd be contacting my Email Provider.
creator: frisée

content: Thank you!!! It is resolved now!

content:
Frisee

Thank you very much indeed for your very prompt and helpful response.

Firstly I apologise for raising the subject of a donation. However it is my intention to make one once I can firmly chuck Microsoft Outlook into the dustbin.

Thank you for your advice. I was gormless in not considering the aspect of the region in the settings (not account settings). There are two options in my downloaded version 126.5.2esr 64 bit version under 'time and date formatting': Application locale: English (United Kingdom) Regional settings locale: English (United Kingdom)

The first of these two options was selected before your reply. Changing it to the second appears to have changed the time of all emails today to the correct UK time. However, as I have changed the format on my inbox, and other screens, to show the time as well as the date on all historic emails I ran 'repair file' in the anticipation that it would change the time to UK time of all historic emails so that they would all be in order, but it has not. They are all still jumbled within the date. Any suggestions of how I can resolve this

Also it would help my understanding of the program if you can explain the difference between the two options under time and date formatting, it might help if there was an explanation alongside these two options.

With my thanks again for your help.
creator: redroone

content:
'Application Locale' should say 'United States'. I assume because that's where the Application comes from. I don't know. But it was clear that Time set to the US wasn't what you wanted - which is why I suggested that you change it to your Region.

The new problem you have, you may have to live with. I would guess that the emails are time-stamped when they come in and are added to the data file. That's a complete guess, of course. I assume that you close TB and re-started it?

Your statement about the emails being 'jumbled within the date' make me think that I haven't understood your problem. Are you saying that the dates are out of order? Click on the 'Date' Header to organise them in either ascending or descending date order.
creator: frisée

content:
Frisbee

Thank you for your very prompt reply.

I am sorry I was not clear about the order in which emails are listed, and on looking at it again it has just dawned on me on what is happening. Thunderbird is using the 12 hour clock, am and pm so am emails are listed and then pm emails and which gives the somewhat 'jumbled' listing. The listing does not show the suffix am or pm.

I have looked back on my outlook program and that uses the 24 hour clock so it is obvious when an email was sent or received.

Either I need it to show am or pm after the time or for it to use the 24 hour clock.

Have you any idea how I can achieve either of these, preferably the 24 hour clock as outlook uses?

Regards and thanks again.
creator: redroone

content:
I would assume that that's a Windows Setting that Thunderbird is using. To change Windows+I/Time and Language/Language and Region/Regional Format/Change Formats And then alter as required. The alterations span all of Windows, including the time in the System Tray

You can do a local change for Thunderbird by following this article: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/customize-date-time-formats-thunderbird#w_create-date-and-time-format-override-preferences-using-thunderbirds-config-editor
creator: frisée

content:
Frizee

Thank you for your prompt response as always.

Problem solved! My system time was correct so I then started to look at the time format which I had set using config editor and the Mozilla article at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/customize-date-time-formats-thunderbird#w_create-date-and-time-format-override-preferences-using-thunderbirds-config-editor

I used the article mentioned within the above article on unicode time formats (very complicated but all you need at the end of the day are the listed format combinations) and find that instead of using 'HH:mm' for the time in 24 hours I had used 'hh:mm' which gave the 12 hour time. So a long saga now resolved.

I am sorry for the time that you have had to spend on this but you did give me the clue which finally allowed the penny to drop and for which I am extremely grateful.

Best wishes and thanks again.
creator: redroone

content: Do a global search for one of those 2025 messages you have archived. In the list of results you can find where your messages have gone by activating the "Location" column, if necessary the "Account" column, too.

I went back there and saw that 2025 was there, but not checked. I checked it and the folder appeared as expected.

Thanks very much
creator: MrYossu

content: Your solution is surprising because the number of messages showing next to each folder cannot be activated via Properties. I guess that this is an IMAP account and you had to click on the Account name > Subscribe .... and then in the Folder List check the 2025 subfolder. But anyhow how you arrived there it's the result which counts!
